Where do they get these figures? No one I know who's unemployed knows anyone else who suddenly got a decent job in the last few months, so what would make anyone think the economy's started to turn around, and after lying back on their laurels, decided to begin looking for work again? People who are unemployed have been continuously looking, and it's hard to believe anyone would say they've just given up unless they can collect social security or are independently wealthy. I don't believe these reports, and no one I know believes them either. We're now into our 55th week and are about to file for social security if nothing comes through in the next few months. It's not enough to live on, let alone pay for health care, but we've managed to sweat it out for a year, using our savings. What do people younger than us do? Then, I guess we'll be considered to have "given up" after going through either a phone or personal interview every few weeks since the lay-off to no avail.

We've seen a lot of recessions and slowdowns (what makes this type of capitalism the best system btw? It's been a stressful rollercoaster for the last 30 years and looks to be that way for the whole working life of young people) but decent jobs came back relatively quickly after a few years. They're just not coming back this time no matter how many jobs have been added to the payroll.

I have now lived 45 years of my life in the only two states that have absolutely NO gambling: Utah and Hawai'i.
I didn't realize how great that was until I moved to Reno, Nevada! Slot machines are everywhere! You get off the airplane and there are slot machines lining the airport. 7-11s, grocery stores all have slots. And most people here go to the casinos for recreation and a night out. And...I have never seen such terrible addiction! People are rewarded with flashing lights, sirens, bells if they win 25 cents. The pit bosses and dealers, the cocktail waitresses are all dressed up beautifully. It is Fantasyland!
And patients can't pay their rent, utilities, clothes for their kids, because gambling comes first.
And to harveydad: The poor are definitely affected worse than any wealthy person. Casinos will cash your check for free! ATM machines in casinos give you $100 bills, not 20s. ATM machines have screens saying: "Is this still fun? If not, call gamblers anonymous 775--"

Casino workers will tell you that the same people sit at the same machines day after day after day. You might see a few well-dressed tourists, but the casinos, especially with Reno's real unemployment rate of 25% are getting their money from locals.

The neon lights, no windows, no clocks make for 24 hour a day wonder land. It is so terribly pathetic. Utah and Hawai'i have it right!

So what will eventually happen is that some reactor vessel somewhere will finally corrode through (or something equally bad) and a Category 7 Nuclear Accident will take place somewhere in the US. Its a matter of when, not if. The NRC, and the parts of the government that oversee the NRC will then say "We are shocked! Shocked that this could happen!" Moments after, someone from GE will hand that NRC regulator his gambling winnings from GE's stock on Wall Street.
I've been to NRC hearings and every time the commissioners have bent over backwards as far as the utilities are concerned, but acted downright hostile against anyone challenging the industry. It was this way while trying to question the blockage of spent fuel expansion at the Trojan Nuclear Plant north of Portland in the late 70s. I heard from others at other hearings that it was always this way, with the regulators always hostile to any opposition.
Fukushima challenges this. That the same reactor designs are used here won't help this industry. Its time that the entire industry from top down be audited and shut down, should the risks prove too great.
I have no problem with people gambling and risk taking on Wall Street basically. But gambling with 104 aging nukes that should be put down is another problem. And we've seen from the housing bubble collapse how risk taking doesn't always work out so well. In the Housing Bubble collapse, the result was mostly inconvenient for many, some painfully so, but the fatality rate is pretty low. But if we lost Indian Point to a Category 7 accident and the wind was blowing to Manhattan, 40 miles downwind, then the results would be catastrophic, with the only silver lining being that Wall Street would be uninhabitable for a long time perhaps! The same mindset and the same pool of money that gambled on the Housing Bubble is gambling on these Nukes. The Housing Bubble didn't work out so well.
A risk that I doubt anyone in the government takes seriously is the potential for a terrorist attack. Yet last week 5 were arrested in Great Britain while taking photos of a reprocessing facility. On 9/11, Mohammed Atta flew one of the planes right over Indian Point. I'm sure some terrorists out there are looking at the havoc taking place at Fukushima and pondering these facts, and could be plotting an attack on an aging and vulnerable nuke somewhere, maybe as revenge for last week's event.
What a can of worms this industry has created! And the final rub? If something bad happens, the Utilities and the Industry are off the hook beyond $540 million dollars, thanks to the Price-Anderson Act. Who gets to pay for the disaster? The US Taxpayer. Fukushima's cleanup could cost trillions. Imagine the cost if New York City had to be abandoned, if Indian Point had a severe accident! We could never recover economically.

In Japan this country is on the brink, which goes unreported, of decimation. Japan is hanging on. Just. Any day the world might wake up and find that a reactor has cracked open, due to the hellish forces inside. The workers will flea. And all the reactors, 1 2 3 4 5 6, will be out of control. And Tokyo will start emptying. And the ocean will start dying. And oncologists will be busy all around the world.
